</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>SPSS won't allow you to add columns with a data type that is not an int or float for examining descriptives. In Python you can add it, but it won't show anything. Given what we saw above we should expect to see descriptive statistics for every column except <strong>purpose</strong> and it appears we do in fact have descriptives for every column except purpose. This provides us more than the base <strong>descriptives</strong> command from SPSS as we also see the <strong>quartiles</strong>.</p>
<p>If we wanted to look at specific columns we would just subset them like this:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'log.annual.inc'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'fico'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">describe</span><span class="p">(),</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[8]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="But-I-hear-you-saying,-that's-great-and-all,-but-I've-used-SPSS-for-so-long-I-like-the-stacked-output-better-than-the-wide-output-(variables-as-rows-instead-of-columns)">But I hear you saying, that's great and all, but I've used SPSS for so long I like the stacked output better than the wide output (variables as rows instead of columns)<a class="anchor-link" href="#But-I-hear-you-saying,-that's-great-and-all,-but-I've-used-SPSS-for-so-long-I-like-the-stacked-output-better-than-the-wide-output-(variables-as-rows-instead-of-columns)">¶</a></h2><p><strong>Well</strong>....the great thing about object oriented programming is the table is an object that can be manipulated.</p>
<p>So....let's think about an easy way to do that. What if we just <strong>transposed the object?</strong></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [37]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">describe</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">transpose</span><span class="p">(),</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[37]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>Now it looks identical to the SPSS output above!</strong></p>
<h1 id="Crosstabs">Crosstabs<a class="anchor-link" href="#Crosstabs">¶</a></h1><p>Another really common output I've used in SPSS is the crosstabs view. It looks a little like this;</p>
<p><img src="https://i.imgur.com/JojWqgu.png" alt="spss_crosstabs"></p>
<p>Just like descriptives, pandas has you covered for crosstabs as well. Now most of these variables are continuous by nature, so in order to make a crosstabs viewable let's quickly bin one that might be interesting to look at. What we want to do is use the following; np.linspace, np.digitize</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.linspace.html">np.linspace</a>looks at the min and the max of the fico score and creates a linearly spaced grouping of them, so all numbers within the min and max are equally grouped into 5 categories.</li>
<li>Then <a href="https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.13.0/reference/generated/numpy.digitize.html">np.digitize</a> returns the index for each bin.</li>
<li>Finally, I build a crosstab so we can examine the number of individuals that either paid back their loan (0) or did not pay back their loan (1).</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">bins</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fico'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">min</span><span class="p">(),</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fico'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">max</span><span class="p">(),</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fico_binned'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">digitize</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fico'</span><span class="p">],</span><span class="n">bins</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'not.fully.paid'</span><span class="p">],</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fico_binned'</span><span class="p">],</span><span class="n">margins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[9]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>You can see a trend where the proportion of borrowers that did not pay back their loans tends to becom less and less as we move from the lowest bins to the highest bins.</strong> Which makes sense. People with lower fico scores typically have those for a reason, perhaps not fiscally responsible with credit?</p>
<h1 id="Correlation-Matrix">Correlation Matrix<a class="anchor-link" href="#Correlation-Matrix">¶</a></h1><p><img src="https://i.imgur.com/47ANLCw.gif" alt="spss_corr"></p>
<p>As an I/O this SPSS output is probably our bread and butter. Examining the correlations amongst your variables. Lucky for us that's also extremely simple to do in pandas. using the <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.corr.html">pandas.DataFrame.corr</a> method.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">(),</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[25]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We could also turn it into a nicer looking heatmap visual by importing the seaborn package.</p>
<p>There are many cmaps available, <a href="https://chrisalbon.com/python/data_visualization/seaborn_color_palettes/">here</a> are a few, but you can also create your own using <a href="https://matplotlib.org/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.colors.LinearSegmentedColormap.html">matplotlibs linear segmented color map functionality</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [34]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">figure</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">heatmap</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">(),</span><span class="n">cmap</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'viridis'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">annot</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Of course this would be great if this was all pandas had to offer.</p>
<h1 id="Other-important-methods-I've-used-over-the-past-few-years-are:">Other important methods I've used over the past few years are:<a class="anchor-link" href="#Other-important-methods-I've-used-over-the-past-few-years-are:">¶</a></h1><ul>
<li><a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.groupby.html">Groupby</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.pivot_table.html">Pivot Tables</a></li>
<li>Along with <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/index.html">many more</a></li>
</ul>
<p>There's also a great external package I want to talk about that allows you to quickly look at most of your data using the most common EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis) methods.</p>
<h1 id="Pandas-Profiling"><a href="https://github.com/pandas-profiling/pandas-profiling">Pandas Profiling</a><a class="anchor-link" href="#Pandas-Profiling">¶</a></h1><p><strong>Note</strong> in order to use pandas profiling (which we will explore next) you will need to install the package. You can do so, by using the following command in your terminal/anaconda prompt:</p>
<p><strong>conda install -c conda-forge pandas-profiling</strong></p>
<p>Let's see what additional features pandas profiling has to offer!</p>
<p>As you can see below the pandas profiling package offers just about everything you could ever want to quickly look through your data.</p>
<p>Here's a quick list:</p>
<ul>
<li>Number of variables</li>
<li>Number of observations</li>
<li>Percent of missing data</li>
<li>Size of the data in memory</li>
<li>data types (numerical, categorical, boolean, etc.)</li>
<li>A flag on features/variables with a large # of zero values</li>
<li>Common statistics (like seen in the .describe() pandas method)</li>
<li>Histograms for each feature/variable</li>
<li>Common values</li>
<li>Extreme values</li>
<li>Pearson correlation</li>
<li>Spearman correlation</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>As far as understanding your data, this is about as good as it gets</strong></p>
<p>You are going to have to scroll down a little ways given the amount of output pandas profiling produces from just 1 line of code, but please do, so we can see if anything jumps out at us.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [36]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas_profiling</span>
<span class="n">pandas_profiling</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ProfileReport</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[36]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Some quick notes from the descriptives:</p>
<ol>
<li>We can clearly see that a number of these variables are incredibly skewed.</li>
<li>The correlation matrix provides us with a few interesting (but understandable) findings:<ul>
<li>Pretty strong negative correlation between interest rate and fico score</li>
<li>Pretty strong positive correlation between credit policy and fico score</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<p>While this is great for a brief overview, we should probably do a bit more digging. For that let's use a package built on top of matplotlib called <a href="https://seaborn.pydata.org/">seaborn</a></p>
<p>Let's look at the relationship between fico score and credit policy a bit closer using graphs.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">figure</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'credit.policy'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'fico'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">hist</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'blue'</span><span class="p">,</span>
                                              <span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">30</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Credit.Policy=1'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'credit.policy'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'fico'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">hist</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'red'</span><span class="p">,</span>
                                              <span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">30</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Credit.Policy=0'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'FICO'</span><span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can clearly see that there are a lot more people that have credit policies of 1 in this dataset, but even so, there is a skew towards lower fico scores for those with a credit policy of 0 and higher scores for those with a credit policy of 1.</p>
<p>We had one variable that was categorical, that we didn't get much data on. Let's use seaborn to create a quick categorical plot of that to see if anything stands out.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">figure</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">11</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">7</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">countplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'purpose'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">hue</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'not.fully.paid'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">palette</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Set2'</span><span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It doesn't look like anything really stands out to me, all of the bar charts look pretty proportional between non-paid loans and paid loans.</p>
<h3 id="This-was-a-quick-overview-of-some-of-the-features-pandas,-pandas-profiling,-matplotlib,-and-seaborn-have-to-offer-for-exploring-data.-I-plan-to-do-a-more-full-EDA-in-a-future-article,-but-I-wanted-to-show-you-what-pandas-had-to-offer-and-how-it-provided-many-similar-capablities-to-SPSS,-plus-a-lot-more.">This was a quick overview of some of the features pandas, pandas profiling, matplotlib, and seaborn have to offer for exploring data. I plan to do a more full EDA in a future article, but I wanted to show you what pandas had to offer and how it provided many similar capablities to SPSS, plus a lot more.<a class="anchor-link" href="#This-was-a-quick-overview-of-some-of-the-features-pandas,-pandas-profiling,-matplotlib,-and-seaborn-have-to-offer-for-exploring-data.-I-plan-to-do-a-more-full-EDA-in-a-future-article,-but-I-wanted-to-show-you-what-pandas-had-to-offer-and-how-it-provided-many-similar-capablities-to-SPSS,-plus-a-lot-more.">¶</a></h3><p>If you want to learn exactly how to do everything I did in a bit more detail and a slower pace I'd highly recommend the python data science bootcamp by Jose Portilla I mentioned <a href="https://www.udemy.com/python-for-data-science-and-machine-learning-bootcamp/?couponCode=CURRENT_PY_DS_ML">here</a> as my plan for this site is to walk you through cool features I think add value to the social scientists tool belt, but not necessarily teach you how to use pandas, or the plotting libraries from scratch.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>

entry.title: Data Wrangling Survey Data in Python

  border-width: 1px;

  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, transparent -40px, transparent 1px, transparent 1px, transparent 100%);
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {

}
@media print {

}
div.cell.selected {

}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {

}

}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;

  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {

}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {

  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;

}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  padding: 0.4em;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. We need the 0 value because of how we size */
  /* .CodeMirror-lines */
  padding: 0;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}

  background-position: right;
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
}
div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Data-Wrangling-Survey-Data-in-Python">Data Wrangling Survey Data in Python<a class="anchor-link" href="#Data-Wrangling-Survey-Data-in-Python">¶</a></h1><p>As all social scientists that have collected data before know the responses are often far from perfect. You have to make decisions on whether to include data across a number of factors.</p>
<p>I've gotten a lot of questions from I/Os about what I/O specific work looks like in Python and the process is very similar to what you traditionally do, just using different syntax. This article will walk through how we cleaned the data we used for the SIOP ML Competition.</p>
<p>Recently, as the host of the <a href="https://evalai.cloudcv.org/web/challenges/challenge-page/160/overview">2019 SIOP Machine Learning Competition</a> our team had to identify criteria for inclusion into the final dataset. We wanted to ensure that the respondents took their task seriously, so we had to identify whether or not an individuals' responses were <strong>quality</strong>, but we couldn't manually review all 2000+, so we had to devise a strategy to do so at scale. That's where manipulating data or <strong>data wrangling/munging</strong>, whichever term you want to use comes into play. In this article I will walk through how we approached this given our criteria using the SIOP ML original dataset.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: Because at this time the competition is still going on I will not do any data viz or discuss any specific items (which isn't even relevant to general cleaning anyway), but will walk through the cleaning process we took.</p>
<h3 id="However,-I-wanted-to-add-that-because-of-Shaker-International's-support-of-open-source-and-open-source-research-they-have-decided-to-make-all-of-the-data-available-after-the-competition-is-completed.-This-includes-the-5-open-ended-SJIs,-the-60-item-level-responses,-and-several-demographic-variables-that-were-collected.-The-total-sample-size-is-1688.">However, I wanted to add that because of <a href="http://shakerinternational.com/">Shaker International's</a> support of open source and open source research they have decided to make all of the data available after the competition is completed. This includes the 5 open-ended SJIs, the 60 item level responses, and several demographic variables that were collected. The total sample size is 1688.<a class="anchor-link" href="#However,-I-wanted-to-add-that-because-of-Shaker-International's-support-of-open-source-and-open-source-research-they-have-decided-to-make-all-of-the-data-available-after-the-competition-is-completed.-This-includes-the-5-open-ended-SJIs,-the-60-item-level-responses,-and-several-demographic-variables-that-were-collected.-The-total-sample-size-is-1688.">¶</a></h3><p><img src="https://i.imgur.com/rPtZ78N.jpg" alt="Data Wrangling"></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Import-Packages">Import Packages<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Packages">¶</a></h1><p>The first thing we always do is import our packages. We'll only be using NumPy and Pandas for this process, I also import warnings because sometimes I get ugly red warnings about <a href="https://pypi.org/project/deprecation/">keyword argument deprecation</a> which just means the newer versions have changed keywords.</p>
<p>You can find out the exact keywords and inputs a method will take by visiting the <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.describe.html">documentation site</a> or in Jupyter by hitting the shift+tab keys when you are in the method of a python argument. The link and image are examples for the pandas.describe() method.</p>
<p><img src="https://i.imgur.com/PZiN06K.png" alt="Method"></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import our packages</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">warnings</span>
<span class="n">warnings</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">filterwarnings</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'ignore'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Load-the-Dataframe">Load the Dataframe<a class="anchor-link" href="#Load-the-Dataframe">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_excel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'data/01_14_19_num_content.xlsx'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Next let's get a count of how many respondents we have in the original dataset by using the <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.Series.count.html">.count() method</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Respondent ID'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">count</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[6]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>1404</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>We have 1404 individuals in our dataset to begin with.</strong></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Overview-of-the-survey-and-the-data">Overview of the survey and the data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Overview-of-the-survey-and-the-data">¶</a></h2><p>The survey consisted of <strong>5 open-ended responses and 65 likert type items along with a few demographic related questions</strong>. The first thing we want to do is <strong>identify all the people that completed the survey</strong>. The questions were all mandatory, until the demographics section, so let's use the last likert type item as the indicator of whether or not they completed the portion of the survey we need.</p>
<p>How would we do that? Well let's create a new column in the dataframe that flags whether or not the last personality item is null or not and assign that to a new variable called <strong>"completed survey"</strong> by writing the code below</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'completed_survey'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Last_P_Item'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isnull</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="kc">True</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Thi <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.Series.isnull.html">.isnull()</a> method returns a boolean of True or False for each row in the column. The pandas <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.apply.html">.apply()</a> method is extremely powerful for data wrangling, which I use often. Additionally when I first learned about <a href="https://www.w3schools.com/python/python_lambda.asp">lambda functions</a> I thought I'd never need them, turns out I was extremely wrong. They are very useful for writing straightforward functions in very little code. The lambda above is a very short if else statement; assign x a 0 if x is equal to True else assign x a 1.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [28]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'completed_survey'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[28]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>1    1188
0     216
Name: completed_survey, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now see that roughly 216 people did not answer all the required questions and 1188 did. So let's subset the dataframe to only include the people that completed the survey.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [29]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_completes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'completed_survey'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Data-Wrangling-the-Open-Ends">Data Wrangling the Open Ends<a class="anchor-link" href="#Data-Wrangling-the-Open-Ends">¶</a></h1><p>In our request for data we asked that all responses be at least 3-4 sentences long, so if the responses aren't very long we want to flag those. Those people did not follow the instructions and their data will not be very useful for the purposes of the competition. We decided 15 words or fewer was a reasonable threshold. So let's look at how we would do this.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Here is what I want this cell to accomplish;  I want to ensure that <strong>all the open-ended responses are of type string</strong>, so I just set them to that to be safe, then I want to loop through all of the open ends, <strong>get the word count</strong>, finally I want to <strong>assign a new variable</strong> a value of 1 if the response was greater than or equal to 15 words or a 0 if it was not.</p>
<p>I've mentioned it before, but you can chain methods together in python. So instead of creating two variables I can just chain both .apply() methods on each other and create 1 variable. After the code cell I will walk through each of the steps in a bit more detail.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">open_ends</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Q1'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q2'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q3'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q4'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q5'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># make a list of the open-ended items</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">open_ends</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">astype</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="s1">'_good'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">()))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">>=</span><span class="mi">15</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Let's-go-through-the-for-loop-in-a-bit-more-detail.">Let's go through the for loop in a bit more detail.<a class="anchor-link" href="#Let's-go-through-the-for-loop-in-a-bit-more-detail.">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li><p><strong>First</strong> we assigned each open end to <a href="https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.astype.html">.astype()</a> string to ensure we can use the .split() method which I'll talk about in a second.</p>
</li>
<li><p><strong>Second</strong> we assign a new feature/variable with the open end name plus an underscore good, so the end results will be Q1_good for example.</p>
</li>
<li><p><strong>Third</strong> let's look at the first lambda function. It asks for the <a href="https://www.programiz.com/python-programming/methods/built-in/len">length</a> of x(which represents whatever is in the specific "cell") <a href="https://www.w3schools.com/python/ref_string_split.asp">split</a> which splits everything in a string on on what you tell it to. The default in a blank method is a space. Let's see how it works below.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Example-of-what-.split()-is-doing">Example of what .split() is doing<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example-of-what-.split()-is-doing">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [35]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">string_1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'I think all I/Os should learn Python because it is so versatile and useful'</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"This is what the split method outputs: "</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">string_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">())</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"This is how many words are in the string_1 object: "</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">string_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">()))</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>This is what the split method outputs:  ['I', 'think', 'all', 'I/Os', 'should', 'learn', 'Python', 'because', 'it', 'is', 'so', 'versatile', 'and', 'useful']
This is how many words are in the string_1 object:  14
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<ul>
<li><strong>Fourth</strong>, we used another lambda if/else statement to assign the variable a value of 1 if the number of words was equal to or greater than 15 or else we assigned it a 0.</li>
</ul>
<p>After we identified which open-ended responses met our criteria we want to identify if all of the individuals responses met this word length requirement, again we are going to use chaining, where we first sum along the row axis and then we identify if that sum equals 5 or not.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [31]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'all_meet_word_length_req'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'Q1_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q2_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q3_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q4_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q5_good'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">5</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We are first summing across the rows of these 5 variables and then we are applying a if/else lambda function where the sum had to equal 5 (meaning all responses were at least 15 words).</p>
<h2 id="Current-Count">Current Count<a class="anchor-link" href="#Current-Count">¶</a></h2><p>Let's look at how many additional people were flagged for not meeting the word length requirement.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [32]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'all_meet_word_length_req'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[32]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>1    1098
0      90
Name: all_meet_word_length_req, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>As you can see this process found 90 individuals that did not meet the requirement of having written at least 15 words to each response</strong></p>
<h1 id="Data-Wrangling-Likert-Items">Data Wrangling Likert Items<a class="anchor-link" href="#Data-Wrangling-Likert-Items">¶</a></h1><p>In addition to flagging open end length we also added in 5 <strong>attention items</strong> to ensure that the respondents were paying attention as they went through the likert items. So let's do something similar for each of those items as well.</p>
<p>Because all of these are slightly different we can't take quite as much advantage of the efficiency we had up above where we just ran it through a for loop. But we can still take advantage of chaining.</p>
<p>In this instance we gave people credit if they answered strongly disagree or disagree for each of the "opinion-based" ones and for the questions where we asked them to mark a specific response we ensured that had to equal that response. Then we summed all the attention check flags together and they needed to have made at least 4 of the attention checks to get credit.</p>
<p>These are all relatively straightforward compared to above, but we used if/else lambdas. Then we again took the sum of the row, but this time we gave some leeway and only flagged them if they missed 2 or more attention checks.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [33]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_Item_1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">5</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_2'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_Item_2'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_3'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_Item_3'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">3</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_4'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_Item_4'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_5'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_Item_5'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Good_Attention_Checks'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_1'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_2'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_3'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_4'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_5'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">>=</span><span class="mi">4</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Putting-it-all-together">Putting it all together<a class="anchor-link" href="#Putting-it-all-together">¶</a></h1><p>We said earlier we wanted them to pass the attention check section <strong>and</strong> meet the word length requirements, so now we have to put it all together. Again, let's sum those two columns and if that equals 2 we'll say they are valid, if not let's discard them as poor respondents.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [34]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'good_attention_&_length'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'Good_Attention_Checks'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'all_meet_word_length_req'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'good_attention_&_length'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[34]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>1    1059
0     129
Name: good_attention_&_length, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>We started with 1404 individuals and after our cleaning criteria we now have 1059 quality responses to include in our final dataset</strong></p>
<p><em>Note:</em> This is isn't all the data that was used in the competition, this was just one main collection effort the final sample consisted of 1688 examples.</p>
<h4 id="We-were-able-to-do-all-of-that-in-15-lines-of-code-(if-you-ignore-the-value_counts-I-used-to-show-what-it-had-done)-and-I'm-not-even-an-efficient-programmer.-I-think-this-really-points-out-the-power-of-using-a-programming-language-outside-of-SPSS-syntax.-Plus-did-I-mention-Python-and-R-are-FREE!!!">We were able to do all of that in 15 lines of code (if you ignore the value_counts I used to show what it had done) and I'm not even an efficient programmer. I think this really points out the power of using a programming language outside of SPSS syntax. Plus did I mention Python and R are <strong>FREE</strong>!!!<a class="anchor-link" href="#We-were-able-to-do-all-of-that-in-15-lines-of-code-(if-you-ignore-the-value_counts-I-used-to-show-what-it-had-done)-and-I'm-not-even-an-efficient-programmer.-I-think-this-really-points-out-the-power-of-using-a-programming-language-outside-of-SPSS-syntax.-Plus-did-I-mention-Python-and-R-are-FREE!!!">¶</a></h4><h1 id="TLDR;">TLDR;<a class="anchor-link" href="#TLDR;">¶</a></h1>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_excel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'data/01_14_19_num_content.xlsx'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'completed_survey'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Is original, comes up with new ideas at work.'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isnull</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="kc">True</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'completed_survey'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">open_ends</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Q1'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q2'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q3'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q4'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q5'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">open_ends</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">astype</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="s1">'_good'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">()))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">>=</span><span class="mi">15</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'all_meet_word_length_req'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'Q1_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q2_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q3_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q4_good'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Q5_good'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">5</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'For attention purposes please mark agree strongly.'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">5</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_2'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'I have never used a computer.'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_3'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'For attention purposes please  mark neutral; no opinion.'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">3</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_4'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'I do not understand a word of english at work.'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_5'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'I can run two miles in two minutes.'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Good_Attention_Checks'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'Attention_1'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_2'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_3'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_4'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Attention_5'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">>=</span><span class="mi">4</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'good_attention_&_length'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_completes</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'Good_Attention_Checks'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'all_meet_word_length_req'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In future articles I plan to go into a bit more detail about data wrangling, data exploration (EDA), data viz during data exploration, etc. But I wanted to briefly show I/Os and other social scientists used to working in SPSS or SAS that it's quick and easy to clean data in Python too. This data, while very relevant to I/Os is being used as part of the competition and I don't want to do and data exploration for them :) After the competition as I mentioned above Shaker International plans to open source this data for all to explore and learn from.</p>
<h1 id="Additional-Resources:">Additional Resources:<a class="anchor-link" href="#Additional-Resources:">¶</a></h1><p>I know I reference Jake VanderPlas' work a lot but he has another great chapter on <a href="https://jakevdp.github.io/PythonDataScienceHandbook/03.00-introduction-to-pandas.html">Pandas</a> in his Python Data Science Handbook.</p>
<p>Another great resource for Pandas is <a href="https://github.com/wesm/pydata-book">Wes Mckinney's book</a> the guy who actually started and wrote the large majority of the Pandas library.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>

entry.title: Python Math vs. NumPy Math: Why should I care about linear algebra as an I/O?

.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {

    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;

  display: -webkit-box;

/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {

}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is

}

}

}
/* any special styling for code cells that are currently running goes here */
div.input {

/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {

}
div.input_area > div.highlight {

div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {

}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;

 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;

}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  padding: 0.4em;

div.output_wrapper {

}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;

  overflow: auto;

  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);

}
